This is obviously where keeps her stash. dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call him then?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: He was the adult. Why didn’t he call me?

dialogues.speaker: DR. PAGE
dialogues.text: Why do you think he didn’t call you? She takes a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Maybe having a family isn’t for everyone. Maybe you think that’s the answer, that that’s what you’re supposed to do because that’s what you've been programmed to do since you were a kid. But maybe that’s not right. I mean, you shouldn’t be allowed to just make babies and fuck up other people’s lives because you think you’re supposed to adhere to this idea that everyone tells you is right. Maybe he thought he was doing me a favor by leaving. A beat. Dr. Page is silent while Laney contemplates what she’s just said.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can we talk about the drugs now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An emotionally exhausted Laney exits the building, cigare in hand. She searches her pockets for a light. Nothing. S breaks her cigarette and throws it on the ground, too ups to notice ZACK (mid-30s) sitting on a nearby bench smokin cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: It gets easier.  Pink (03/02/2014) 39. Zack walks over to Laney, hands her a cigarette and light for her. He is boyishly good looking, charismatic, and ha strong penchant for sarcasm. Laney takes a deep drag, eye Zack skeptically, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Heh, I don’t know yet. That’s just what they tell me. You just check in?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Couple days ago. But I really shouldn’t be here. No offense, this just isn’t the kind of place I should be in.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What kind of place should you be in? Laney takes a drag off her cigarette, searches her surroundings for an answer but comes up short.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Not this place. It’s depressing.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. I feel you. Last week was good though. Whole staff was all freakin out. They fired one of the nurses. Exciting.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: For what? Smiling? Zack laughs, he likes her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: No. She got caught having sex with a patient in a broom closet.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No way. What happened to the patient?

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Just a slap on the wrist. Zack holds up his wrist to show her.  Pink (03/02/2014) 40. ZACK (CONT’D) Bruise is almost gone. Laney looks at Zack surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m Zack by the way.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Laney.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you Laney.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Likewise. They smile at each other, an immediate chemistry. Zack drops his cigarette on the ground and puts it out wi his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: When you figure out what kind of place you should be in let me know. Maybe that’s where I should be too. Zack leaves but looks back at Laney over his shoulder wit beguiling smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney picks up the pay phone, inserts some quarters and c Bruce. One ring. Two rings. She begins to fidget, wraps the phone cord around her finger. Three rings. Then...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey. How’s it going? In the background Laney can hear cartoons, kids, minor ch

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Uh, it’s good. It’s going good. How are you guys doing?  Pink (03/02/2014) 41.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good. Kids are wiped out. Getting ready for bed. Big day ice- skating.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You went ice-skating? Without me?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Laney--

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: We always go ice-skating together. Laney is getting agitated.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s kind of our thing.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know Lane but you’re not here. Would you rather I didn’t take them?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No, it’s just I should have been there. Laney fights back tears. A NURSE approaches her with a sm tray in his hand, a handful of small paper cups with name them, and equal amount of cups of water. He hands her the “Laney” cup, she turns her back to him. He taps her shoul and she turns around and takes the meds without argument.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It’s only been a week Lane. Just focus on getting better. The kids need you, I need you. Janey can be heard calling, “Daddy!” in the background. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Lane. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Wait, can I say good night?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to upset them before bed. We'll see you at family visit.  49 Pink (03/02/2014) 42. Janey calls for “Daddy!” again.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Laney. I have to go. I love you. We all love you and miss you here.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I love you too. Laney hangs up the phone and breaks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s cold out but Laney doesn’t seem to mind it. She sits alone on the porch and contemplates the starlit sky. Zack joins her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: I understand if you have a death wish but it sucks when you only get pneumonia and can’t take the good meds. Zack takes his jacket off and wraps it around Laney’s shoulders. He sits down next to her, hands her a cigarett lights it. Lights his own.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Thanks. They sit for a moment staring at the sky until Laney, fighting tears, breaks the silence. Laney bites a cuticle Zack sees her wedding band.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: How long have you been married?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Forever.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Lucky guy. Laney is flattered but restrains herself.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Not sure he’d agree with that. But thanks. (pause) How fucking great would a shot of tequila be right now?  50 Pink (03/02/2014) 43.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: With a little lime.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: And salt. Zack holds out his cigarette to hers, they bump them together.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s visiting day. The room is filled with VISITORS. Zack sits close to a beautiful, wholesome, blond. He tucks a l of hair behind her ear. Laney watches the exchange. Janey and Eli are in line for dessert. Bruce and Laney ar sitting at a table. Some time has passed. Laney looks muc better, clear eyed. Bruce pushes his food around with his fork.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You look great. You feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Do you feel like you’re making progress?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just say what you’re thinking?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Why are you so angry?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m not angry. Laney glances at Eli and Janey at the dessert table.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not. I’m not angry. I’m scared Bruce. I’m scared of everything.  Pink (03/02/2014) 44,

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Like what? What are you scared of?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Everything. I know you think that if I just take my medication that everything will go back to the way it was but it’s bigger than that. Laney glances back at Eli.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s Eli doing with his eyes? We see Eli twitch.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When did he start doing that? Bruce doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he doing that in school?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. No one’s called me about it.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You can’t wait for someone to call you. What if kids are making fun of him? You have to call his teacher and find out what’s happening. The both watch Eli for a moment, still twitching.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Promise me you'll call his teacher. Bruce puts his hand on top of hers.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I promise Lane. I’11 make sure he’s okay. Laney takes a breath and pulls her hands away.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I need to tell you something Bruce. I need to tell you some things, some really fucking terrible things I did when I wasn’t thinking clearly but I need you to know so I... so we can start fresh.  Pink (03/02/2014) 45.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Don’t do this now Laney. You’ve got a lot on your mind.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No this is important. I need to do this-- Bruce looks over at the kids piling their plates high wit brownies.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Come on guys, that’s enough. Come sit down. The kids return, all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: They have chocolate cake and brownies daddy! I like it here! Bruce pulls Janey onto his lap, a human shield. Laney fig the tears and musters a fake smile for Janey. Bruce meets Laney’s eyes, but he has to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney is holding Eli’s hand as they walk down a path towa the parking lot. (Eli has his huge knapsack on his back.) Bruce and Janey are walking ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I brought you something. As he looks at her he rolls his eyes back in his head, twitches them, squeezes them open and shut, rolls them ag He doesn’t seem to notice that a ferocious tick has taken over his eyeballs. Bruce and Laney look at each other, th are no words. Bruce shakes his head and shrugs, unlocks t door. Eli drops his knapsack to the ground, opens it and begins digging.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I made this for you. He hands her a hard object wrapped in newspaper. It says “MOM” in purple crayon. Laney unwraps the gift. It is perhaps the most beautiful thing she has ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You made me a dream catcher?  52 Pink (03/02/2014) 46. Eli, still eye twitching.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yep. No more bad dreams.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It's beautiful E. Thank you. The kids get in the car. She helps buckle them in. Gives them each a kiss goodbye. Bruce comes around to her side the car to say goodbye. Laney has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Promise me you’ll call the school psychologist or Eli’s teacher first thing in the morning. Bruce puts his hands on her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Focus on getting better Lane. So you can come home. We need you. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you. They get in the car. Laney stands in the parking lot and waves as she watches them drive away. In the background w see a WOMAN (60's) hugging two YOUNG MEN goodbye. As both cars are pulling out of the parking lot we see La and the woman both standing alone, 20 feet away from each other, Laney with the dream catcher in her hand. They are same. No words are exchanged. Yet there is an implicit understanding between them: if only they could be in thos cars. If only it was as simple as driving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney is jogging along the path. Zack runs up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: You've been avoiding me for a while now and I’m starting to take it personally. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though it’s hard to imagine I could ever do anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m not avoiding you. Laney doesn’t look at Zack.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took up reading.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Reading is good. (Pause) Are you pissed at me or something?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Why would I be pissed at you? Laney keeps running, Zack stops, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Can you just stop for a minute? Laney stops, turns around. They’re both breathing heavily ZACK (CONT’D) I don’t know you just seem pissed. Everything okay? Kids okay?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Everything's fine. Good actually. I've been working really hard in therapy. Finally getting somewhere. What about you? How’s your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: My girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: The girl who comes on visiting day. The blond.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Sienna? Sienna is good.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: That’s great. Happy to hear that. Zack looks at her with grave curiosity. A charming smile spreads across his face.  Pink (03/02/2014) 48.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: You're jealous? That’s what this is about? Laney is embarrassed. For the first time we see her vulnerable. ZACK (CONT’D) I don’t mean to be the messenger of irony or anything but you're married. So unless you’re not telling me something...

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I know, you’re right. Maybe I am jealous. Zack kisses her, she gives in for a moment before she pus him away.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Whoa. I’m kinda getting mixed signals here.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. God. I’m really sorry. Zack looks away, uncomfortable. Laney places a hand on hi cheek and forces him to look at her. This is Laney. Vulnerable. Sweet. Spoiled. Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zack- listen to me. I’ve made some really stupid decisions in my life. And as much as I’d love to be with you it would just be one more bad choice. I need to remember how to be a friend. You know? I want to be a friend to you. A good friend. And I need to remember how to be a good wife and mother. How to just- be a real person. I’ve spent so much time running away from my problems because I didn’t want to feel any pain and I’ve fucked up everything in my life. Good things.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: I hear that. And you are a real person Laney. A great person.  53 Pink (03/02/2014) 49,

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’m working on it. I’ve gotta try. I deserve to try. My kids deserve that. Zack takes in his feelings for a moment before he masks t with his trademark humor.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: So I guess I won’t be getting you in the broom closet then? They laugh and Laney looks at Zack with pure endearment a gratitude. They hug each other, long and honest.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I have to go. See you at movie night?

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Popcorn’s on me. As she walks towards the camera, Zack calls from behind h in the distance. ZACK (CONT’D) By the way- Sienna is my sister! Laney stops for a moment of surprise. She smiles to herse and keeps walking. INT. DR. PAGE’S OFFICE - DAY - SAME 53 Laney sits on her familiar chair, Dr. Page sits in his ch behind the desk. They are observing each other in silence

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You know the night before I came here, even with everything I did that night, I went into Eli’s room to check on him. I sat down on the edge of his bed. I just wanted to watch him breathe. And I thought to myself, he'll never know. Neither of them will ever know how hard I tried not to hurt them. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Am I gonna fuck this up? I really don’t want to fuck this up.  54 Pink (03/02/2014) 50.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PAGE
dialogues.text: Have some faith in yourself Laney. You've made unbelievable progress since you got here. Don’t you see that?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I do. Thank you for making me stay.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PAGE
dialogues.text: I didn’t make you stay. That was your choice. And it was a good one. Laney smiles at Dr. Page. He has empowered her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney says goodbye to Nurse Pauline and gives her a heart hug. Zack walks over.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Tell me you weren't going to leave without saying goodbye. Laney smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I suck at good-byes.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: I’m going to miss you. Laney glances through the window and sees Bruce drive up.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna miss you too Zack. Will you call me when you’re out?

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: Yep. I think I’m gonna hang here for a couple more weeks though. Nothing for me to rush home to.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I think that’s a great idea. Laney gives Zack a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My ride is here. Zack looks out the doors and sees Bruce waiting against t car.  55 56 57 Pink (03/02/2014) 51.

dialogues.speaker: ZACK
dialogues.text: That’s the guy you blew me off for? I could totally take that guy. They laugh like two old friends with an inside joke. ZACK (CONT’D) Go on. Get outta here and don’t come back. He smiles. Laney grabs her bag and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is leaning against the side of the running car. Lan walks out the door, looks at her husband. He smiles at he and to her surprise, without trying, she smiles back. EXT. BROOK’S HOUSE - NIGHT - SAME 56 A handmade “Welcome Home Mommy” sign is hanging (half on/ half off) the front door. Laney’s SUV is parked in the driveway. Lights are glowing from inside the home

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney and Janey are icing a cake. There is a fire in the fireplace. It’s a lovely and traditional scene. Janey is wearing a nightgown. Eli is wearing a Knicks Jersey. Bing trying to jump up, looking for attention.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Eli, want to ice the cake with us?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No thanks. Janey starts whining that she can’t get it perfect.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: It’s not the way I pictured it. It’s not perfect. Janey is getting really upset. Laney bends down, wraps he arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It is perfect. It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: No it’s not.  Pink (03/02/2014) 52. Janey begins sobbing. Laney tries to calm her down. Eli w over, puts his arm around his sister’s shoulder. Laney lo at him unsure, desperate almost.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why you’re crying. It’s a beautiful cake. Isn’t it Eli?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I like it. Bruce comes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Basement’s dry. Bruce sees Janey crying.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like her cake.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: But that’s a great cake Janey. It’s the best cake I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Really. Can I smell it? Does it smell as good as it looks?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Okay. Bruce leans over the cake and purposely puts his nose in frosting. Janey starts giggling.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yep, it smells as good as it looks!

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Your nose!  Pink (03/02/2014) 53.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with my nose? Bruce pretends like he doesn’t know there is frosting on nose. He feels all around his face, everywhere but the frosting on his nose. Janey is now laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: I want to smell it! Janey sticks her nose in the frosting. Bruce motions to h nose.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Oh, you’ve got a little something. Pretending she doesn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Just a little....

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: What? Laney comes over, aware of the fun.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Can I smell?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Yes! Smell it mommy! It smells great! Laney leans over to smell the cake, Bruce pushes her head into it a little further, teasingly. Laney has frosting covering her nose and a bit of her face.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: That is the best smelling cake. It really is. Eli watches the happy moment, for now he’s an outsider as Bruce, Laney and Janey play with the cake and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hey E, come smell the cake! Eli shrugs his shoulders. He’s not buying into the happy family yet. Laney understands. In the midst of the fun, t power goes out. It’s pitch black.  Pink (03/02/2014) 54.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Mommy !

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It’s okay Muffin, the power just went out. It’ll be back soon. Bruce can you find some candles? Bruce retrieves a handful of candles from a kitchen drawe He lights one, we can see a little. Laney helps him to li more. Janey is quietly crying. In a matter of seconds the kitchen is lit up, candles all around. Candlelight and no full of frosting.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (to Janey) See? Look at that!

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (to Janey) Better?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Here, here’s one just for you. Bruce puts a candle in the cake right next to Janey who i still lightly sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Bruce lights the candle, which lights up Janey’s face. He crying fades.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (begins to sing softly) This little light of mine, I’m gonna let it shine. This little light of mine I’m gonna let it shine. Laney cautiously joins in.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY AND BRUCE
dialogues.text: This little light of mine, I’m gonna let it shine, let it shine let it shine let it shine.  58 Pink (03/02/2014) 55. Bruce takes Laney’s hand, this is a very happy and romant scene. He begins to dance with her, both with frosted nos and somewhat cautious. Eli can’t help but watch, hints of smile on his face. Janey is smiling ear to ear. She joins singing.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, LANEY AND JANEY
dialogues.text: Down in my heart, I’m gonna let it shine. Down in my heart, I’m gonna let it shine. Bruce takes Janey’s hand and pulls her off the bar stool. starts to dance with her. She smiles. Laney turns to Eli, waves him over. He resists, hands in pockets. She waves him over again. This time he comes. BRUCE, LANEY AND JANEY (CONT’D) Down in my heart, I’m gonna let it shine, let it shine, let it shine let it shine. Now they are all dancing in the kitchen by candlelight. L takes a swipe of icing off her nose and puts it on Eli’s. They are all laughing. Bruce puts his arm around Laney, l her nose playfully, they continue to dance. PULL BACK: The camera begins to pull back revealing the glowing kitchen, the family is dancing, their voices fade

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney is standing in the hallway just outside the element school guidance councilor’s office. She is wearing her pa badge around her neck, Janey next to her is wearing her tiara. Eli and Bruce are playing with his iPhone. A mom i passing through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Hey Jessica! Jessica gives Laney a dismissive smile and wave, carries down the hall. Laney is slightly dejected, Bruce sees the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ignore it. MR. ODESKY, the guidance councilor, open’s his office doo

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY
dialogues.text: Come on in. (to Eli and Janey) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to speak to your mom and dad for a few minutes. Can you wait right here?

dialogues.speaker: ELI AND JANEY
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. MR. ODESKY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 59 Mr. Odesky motions for Laney and Bruce to sit.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you both. Mr. Odesky takes his chair behind his desk and motions to empty chairs across from him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, take a seat. Mr. Odesky has a file on his desk which he seems to be familiar with. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s the re-entry going?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: A little choppy.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t hate you.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: He hasn’t forgiven me yet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY
dialogues.text: You need to give him time. Build back his trust. He’s scared you're going to leave again. That’s a rational fear.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m glad you called me Mr. Brooks. I think we need to be proactive in this situation. Mrs. Zeldis is concerned about Eli’s recent behavior in class. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One of the issue’s is that he’s being disruptive.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY
dialogues.text: He interrupts Mrs. Zeldis in the middle of her lessons- asks questions he knows the answers to. It's a way to get attention. She’s working on that. But what concerns me more are his rituals. The eye blinking, the constant pencil sharpening. Recently he’s started a pattern with tapping his feet. Bruce and Laney look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These behaviors suggest anxiety; the rituals are a way for Eli to stay in control. Laney looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not unusual but it becomes a problem when the rituals get in the way of functioning. When they become all consuming.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ODESKY
dialogues.text: In my opinion Eli needs to see a specialist. Perhaps start with Cognitive Behavior Therapy. Or perhaps he can even benefit from medication.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Medication?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (to Bruce) This is my fault. He has my genes.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (under her breath) He never had a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is reading “The Three Little Pigs” to Janey.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And this little piggy went weeeeee weeeeee weeeee all the way home. He tickles her. Laney and Bruce exit office and are met w their laughter. A relief.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Anyone here in the mood for some ice cream!?

dialogues.speaker: ELI AND JANEY
dialogues.text: Me! Laney smiles. She takes Eli’s hand, Bruce and Janey follo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, Laney, Eli and Janey are walking to the car. Laney Eli still holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Did you go to rehab because you're a drug addict? Laney looks to Bruce. Bruce shakes his head. He’s irritat

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. Where did you get that idea?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: John Frye said you’re a drug addict and that’s why you went to rehab.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Drugs are bad mommy.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s not why she was there Eli. John Frye is just trying to get your goat.  Pink (03/02/2014) 59.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Eli doesn’t have a goat.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Then why were you there? Laney stops walking and turns to Eli. She bends down on h knee and puts her hand on his back, bringing him closer t her. His eyes start twitching.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I was having some troubles in my mind. And because of those troubles I started doing some things that I shouldn't have been doing.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Then why did you do them?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s complicated. Laney cups her hands gently around his eyes as if to calm them and stop the twitching.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I saw a doctor who was very smart and he helped me make sense of my troubles. And now I feel a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Odesky tell you to send me to rehab too? Laney hugs him tight. Bruce looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four are looking in the window at the flavors of ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What are you getting mom?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. There is a pimply teenager behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: What’s it gonna be?  Pink (03/02/2014) 60.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: I want the pink one please.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: And I‘1ll have a small scoop of chocolate. Kid size.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: We don’t do kid size for adults. Laney’s instinct is to get irritated. She calms herself.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I'll pay for a regular scoop - just make it in a kid cup.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: I can’t do that either. I'd have to charge you for the cup size I give you.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (deep breath) Fine. I’1l have a small.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I'll have a scoop of vanilla on a sugar cone. The teenager gives them their orders.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: And the little man? Laney waits for Eli to make his choice but Eli doesn’t sa anything. His eyes start contorting furiously.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What do you want Eli? Rocky Road? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Which one Eli? E? What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The lines. Look at the ice cream mom. See how the edges of the containers don’t connect to each other? And the floor is crooked? If I do this with my eyes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Pink (03/02/2014) 61. Eli rolls his eyes up into his head, holds them there, bl hard.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It makes them all straight and I can figure everything out. Laney takes a deep breath. She looks to Bruce for help. B gets down on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You know Buddy, straightening out all the uneven lines in the world is a big job. Let’s just pick a good flavor for now. INT. LANEY’S BATHROOM —- MORNING 62A Laney finishes brushing her teeth, spits, rinses her toothbrush. She opens the medicine cabinet, puts her toothbrush away and takes out a bottle of medication. She unscrews the cap and taps a pill into the palm of her han puts it in her mouth and draws some water out of the fauc to wash it down. Laney closes the medicine cabinet, glanc at herself in the mirror. She fixes her hair, tilts her h She is content with what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney and Eli are perusing the super-hero aisle of a toy store. Eli holds a plastic baggy filled with crumpled bil and coins.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Mom! Look at this one! It’s so cool.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Really cool. Just then Donny and Henry come around the corner. Donny h that split second where one decides if they pretend not t see you, or face the music. In that same second, Henry sp Eli. Decision made. Laney and Donny are both taken off guard.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eli!

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hey Henry!  Pink (03/02/2014) 62.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Look who's here!

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Hey Donny. Hey Henry. Donny and Laney give each other a weak hug.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Good to see you back.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Good to be back. Henry and Eli try to solve the superhero dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Which one are you getting?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I have to see what I can afford. I have fourteen dollars and eighty- two cents.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s a lot.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I'd pick a superhero if I were you Eli. Personally, I always wanted to be the kind of superhero that swoops down, rescues the woman from the burning building and flies her to safety. This is clearly for Laney’s benefit.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So you can’t be Batman cuz he doesn’t fly.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And Spiderman doesn’t really fly, he swings.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: What do you guys think? What kind of superhero should I be? Maybe Superman? I’d be a good Superman, heh?  Pink (03/02/2014) 63. Behind Donny, Susan comes walking down the aisle carrying infant seat. She’s very noticeably pregnant. Laney can’t believe her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Looks like you're already a superhero Donny. Susan approaches Laney with a warm smile and a hug.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Laney! So good to see you! I’ve missed you!

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I had no idea you were pregnant! You're glowing!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh bullshit. I look like shit and I feel like shit. But I’m almost halfway through, thankfully. Donny is uncomfortable, Laney does some math in her head.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: That’s great. Really great you two. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hey- did you get my message? About my birthday party?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Yes! I’m so sorry. I did, I’ve just been so busy trying to catch up on things--

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s fine! I just wanted to make sure you know it’s no pressure. Really. I totally understand if you'd rather skip it.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No, we're looking forward to it. Eli interrupts, thrilled with his choice.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Can I get this one mom?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Good choice my man. Laney puts her arm around Eli’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: We have to get going E. (to Donny and Susan) See you next weekend?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY SHERYL
dialogues.text: See you soon. Can’t wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s bedtime. Janey’s wearing an adorable nightgown. Jane snuggles beneath the covers.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: I have a wish.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: What’s your wish?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: I can’t tell it to you.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Because it won’t come true.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Well, whoever told you that must not know about the ‘Mommy Clause.’

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: The ‘Mommy Clause?’

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You can always tell your mommy a wish.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Good.  65 Pink (03/02/2014) 65. Janey throws her arms around Laney’s shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish you would love me forever.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You never have to worry about that, baby. I’11 always love you.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Forever?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Forever. Now close you're eyes, it’s bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I told you Honey- Mommy and Daddy are going to a birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: No! Don’t go! I don’t want you to leave! Janey goes from 0 to 60 in a second. A full blown tantrum ensues.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Janey we’re just going for a few hours! I’1l be here when you wake up in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: No! No! Don’t leave me! Mommy! Stay here! Bruce has obviously heard the screaming and he appears in doorway wearing a suit. Janey throws her arms around Lane if she can stop her- all the while screaming and crying. Laney looks to Bruce for help, Bruce let’s out a deep sig frustration.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can’t leave me mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Laney are mid slow-dance on the dance floor but Laney is a million miles away.  66 67 Pink (03/02/2014) 66.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hey. You okay? Laney just shakes her head, she’s seems overwhelmed with sadness. A tear streams down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just separation anxiety Lane. All kids do that.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I know- They dance for a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to go call them okay? Bruce nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Of course. I’11 be at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney reaches into her bag and pulls out a cigarette. Whe she looks up Donny is facing her. He’s obviously followed out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: The way you move out there on the dance floor -if I were Bruce I'd get you your own pole. Laney puts the cigarette in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Light? Donny pulls a lighter out of his jacket pocket and lights cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Like a million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Laney glances at her reflection in the club's window. She pushes her hair behind her ear.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: You know, I was going to call you but then I thought I'd done enough, you know. Caused enough damage.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t your fault, Donny. You could have been any man.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: (insulted) Really?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it like that. I just meant that I was looking for something - guess I'm still looking. Of course, it makes it harder that I don't know what I'm looking for. Laney’s amused.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were there and willing, and I thought- well it doesn't matter. Don't worry. You didn't drive me to rehab. Donny is perversely disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I took your advice. Susan and I - we've been working it out.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I saw.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know. When we had our thing-- I didn’t know she was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Our thing?  Pink (03/02/2014) 68.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I want to make sure you know I had no idea.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about. Donny waits a beat. He is, in spite of his wounded ego, appreciative.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m here for you, you know. If you ever need anything. Call me.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks. Donny opens the door to return to the party, stops a beat then...

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I mean. Not my house. Call my office. You need anything you talk to Janine. Okay? Anything. Laney smirks, acutely aware of his audacity. Donny digs h cigarette into the concrete with his shoe and makes his w back into the restaurant. Laney dials a number on her cel phone and holds it against her ear.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It’s mommy. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: That’s good. Your sister sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's sleeping.  68 Pink (03/02/2014) 69.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Eli?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You know I love you right?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Nah. Not really. Not how much. Laney can hear him breathing.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to promise me E. Promise me that you'll always remember that I love you. That I really really love you.

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I promise. Laney takes her forefinger and wipes under each of her ey

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom, can I go now? I’m gonna miss the rest of the game.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Of course. Go. Good night Sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Laney are sitting at a table near the dance flo with DAVID BLACKMAN (mid-fifties) and his trophy wife KAT (mid-twenties). David is a slick looking garmento, Katrin has quite the jewelry wardrobe. The table is rife with alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I cover all of that in the book but to answer your question, there really is no such thing as having too much life insurance. Especially if you’re planning on having more kids. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And no offense David because you look like you're in great shape, but I’m guessing Katrina is going to outlive you. Bruce is playfully ribbing him while expertly navigating waters of business and personal. David laughs, he obvious finds Bruce charming.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's my plan. Plucked this one straight out of high school. Katrina elbows him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA
dialogues.text: I was almost out of college.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Well, the book covers lots of unique scenarios. I see it like this David. There’s a bible for the afterlife. I wrote the bible for the here and now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well it sounds brilliant. The whole notion of hedging your bet against God. A WAITER arrives with a tray of cocktails. Laney pulls a lollipop out of her purse and starts sucking on it.

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA
dialogues.text: You know, I’ve always dreamed of writing a book. How did you do it, Bruce? Did you just sit down and type what you were thinking into a computer or did you pay someone to help you?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: It's sentence by sentence. Anyone can do it. Call me anytime. I'd be happy to help you. Bruce takes his business card out of his wallet, passes i across the table. He is a professional.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: What do you want to write a book about?  Pink (03/02/2014) 71.

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA
dialogues.text: Like, maybe a children’s book or something. I’m not sure yet. Laney feigns interest in her.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You know Katrina, I'm thinking of writing a book too.

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA
dialogues.text: Really, on what?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: On prostitution.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Prostitution? Honey what do you know about prostitution?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Well I’ve been thinking about it. Prostitution is the perfect example of hypocrisy. It's illegal to sell your body. But when you're rich it's perfectly acceptable. We just call it being a wife. Bruce looks at her with hardened eyes. Laney smiles, retu the stare.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think Katrina? Katrina doesn’t know how to respond. Across the room Donn taps a spoon against a champagne glass. The guests quiet.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I'd like to make a toast to my beautiful wife. Susan's right up next to him, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you guys are here to dance and have fun so I'm going to make this short. Suze, I just want you to know, when I drive away to work each morning and see you there waving to me, Henry by your side, all I'm thinking is how fast can I get back to you. Thank you for putting up with me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I can be a real pain-in-the- ass sometimes. Happy Birthday Honey. The room quiets for a collective awwwww. Donny puts his h on Susan’s pregnant belly.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And thank you for this. He turns to the audience.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you believe it? Another baby this woman's having with me. She’s a saint. Donny draws Susan close and begins kissing her. Laney smi and claps in synchronicity with the guests. INT. LANEY AND BRUCE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - SAME 69 Laney is stretched out on the bed. She watches Bruce as h undoes his tie, unbuttons his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: When are you gonna to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Why would you do that? Say you're going to check on the kids and then you come back babbling about prostitution? I was this close to getting David Blackman as a client.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Do you? Do you have any idea how hard I work to keep it all going? Because you act like it's all some big joke. Like what I do for a living is beneath you somehow.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I said I'm sorry. I really am. And I do know how hard you work. I don’t know what I was thinking. Come here.  Pink (03/02/2014) 73. Laney pats the side of the bed with her hand. Bruce relax and sits down next to her. Laney takes his hand and looks him sweetly. He smiles at her, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really am sorry. It was out of line. She was just such a--

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Prostitute? They laugh, real and true. Finally a joke not at their ow expense. A silent moment passes while Bruce changes his t

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come with me to the conference this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t know Bruce. You know how those things are. Everybody’s shit- faced for three straight days.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Not us. Nothing stronger than water for me either. We can lay in bed. Get a massage.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: What about the kids?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: They can stay with my sister.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: They're having a hard enough time as it is.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: They'll be fine. Happy parents make happy kids. We need this. Come on. A road trip. Laney glances up at the ceiling. She rolls over to face h His eyes are earnest. Warm.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: What if I run into my dad? Bruce is saddened by this.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: We don’t have to leave the hotel.  70 71 Pink (03/02/2014) 74. Bruce takes Laney into his arms, kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just think about it. You look tired. He turns off the lamp, fluffs his pillow and rolls onto h side. Laney stares at the ceiling. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I‘1l go with you. ON: Bruce. A softness coming to his face. He reaches around her waist and pulls her close into spoo position, kisses the back of her head and closes his eyes

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Thank you. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: God I hate upstate.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You don’t hate upstate. You hate your dad.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I think I hate both. Can’t I hate both? Bruce chuckles, holds her tight.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yes. You can hate both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is watching Laney sleep. He pushes a lock of hair f her forehead, waking her.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Rise and shine Beautiful. Laney reluctantly wakes. She sees the room service cart.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pancakes and coffee.  Pink (03/02/2014) 75. Laney smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Bacon?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Of course! Laney sits up. A tuxedo and a gown are hanging on a door.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I have to call housekeeping to get those steamed. She picks up the phone to dial and Bruce stops her.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Wait a sec- He hands her a cup of coffee and a small jewelry box.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Oh no. What did you do? Bruce smiles. Inside the box is a beautiful diamond weddi band. Laney is deeply touched.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who would have thought you’d be able to give me a ring like this? Bruce kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me The Newsstand Story.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: The Newsstand Story? You don’t want to hear the Newsstand Story.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I do. I want to hear The Newsstand Story. Please? And I want a massage.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: High maintenance. Okay, roll over. Laney rolls over, a gentle smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there was this incredibly good looking kid.  Pink (03/02/2014) 76.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Awkward.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, different story. Once upon a time there was this incredibly awkward kid from Teaneck. He used to make a couple bucks racking magazines at a store around the corner from his house. He was usually bored out of his skull but one day this knockout comes in. Long black hair. Long thin legs. And she even had nice... Bruce holds his hands out in front of his chest, mimickin giant boobs.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there was something about her. Her eyes, they seemed...sweet.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Seemed sweet or were sweet?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Just let me tell the story. So he started dressing up a little for work--

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Bullshit. He wore T-shirts

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: If you knew how carefully he selected them for fit and color-- Laney laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Point is, everyday, all he could think about was the next time she'd come back.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Awwww.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Then one day she comes in and asks the old man behind the counter to get her a pack of smokes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When he turned around, she boosted a candy bar and stuck it down her pants, paid for her cigarettes and walked out. But before she left she turned around and gave the kid this big huge smile. Blew his mind. He thought-- "this chick is hot and crazy.” So he followed her out of the store thinking he was gonna get the nerve to talk to her. But then... then she did the thing that just owned him. She went around the corner and gave the candy bar to the homeless guy who lived in the alley. Kid was done. From that moment she owned him. He wanted to marry that girl.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: And did he?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yes he did.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Even though she told him not to?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yep. Even though you told me not to.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You know there’s something really wrong with you, right? Bruce runs his fingers through her hair and gives her a s kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I’d marry you a hundred times. They share a loving moment in silence. Bruce glances at h watch and starts to get off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna hop in the shower, don’t want to be late. Laney pulls him back into bed.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Let’s fuck first.  72 73 Pink (03/02/2014) 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, in a casual suit, grins the grin of the satiated m

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want to go with me?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: As much as I love a good insurance seminar...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Very funny. I’1l be back by five to shower. Cocktails at six. Awards at seven.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’1ll be ready.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I called the concierge. He said there’s an AA meeting not far. Just a cab ride. Think about it?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Of course. She opens a prescription container, pops a pill and smile for Bruce’s benefit. Bruce gives Laney a kiss on the chee and she follows him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a good time. Across the hall an elderly man struggles slightly to slid the dirty room service tray out of his room and into the hallway. Laney watches him intently. He smiles at her and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney is in the backseat of a moving taxi. She takes a cigarette out of her bag.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Mind if I smoke? The driver responds by rolling down the windows. Laney li her cigarette.  74 Pink (03/02/2014) 79. They pass through a series of neighborhoods before they p up to a modest but charming ranch house. Laney gets out o the cab and walks up the driveway. EXT. LANEY’S FATHER’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 74 Laney rings the doorbell. DAISY (10) answers the door. La glances at the number on the door to make sure she has th right house.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Oh-hello, is -ah-

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sweetheart you have to ask who it is before you open the door. Laney stares at Daisy for a moment before she turns her g to Roger who is walking toward the door. Awkward silence. takes him second but then he realizes - takes a breath an instinctively puts a protective arm around Daisy's should the way one would do when confronted by a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elaine? Roger is silent, staring in amazement. Daisy looks up to in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Uh-come in. What a surprise. Uh Daisy-this is Elaine. She’s- Laney reaches her hand out to shake Daisy’s.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I knew your dad a long time ago. You can call me Laney.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Do you like doll houses?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Me and my daddy are playing with mine. Want to see it? The door closes.  Pink (03/02/2014) 80. 75 INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM - DAY - SAME 75 A dream bedroom for a little girl: Barbie dolls and stuff animals. A canopy bed. There are several framed family photos on a book shelf. Laney takes them in.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Did you have a dollhouse when you were little?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I sure did.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: What color?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Yellow with blue shutters. Laney looks at her father. A moment is had between them. Laney collects the wooden family members. One by one she brings them into the living room, seats them on the couch The mother in her checkered apron, the father, daughter between them, baby in bassinet.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I like it better when everyone’s in the same room.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Me too. Can I show her my bike daddy? 76 EXT. ROGER’S HOUSE - SAME 76 Roger helps Daisy put her bike helmet on.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Wow, a helmet. Huh.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: All these laws- all this PC garbage to keep your kid safe. The helmets, the car seats, the this and that. They didn’t have that when you were a kid and look at you! You got through it just fine.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just fine Dad. A long, awkward silence as they watch Daisy ride around o her bike.  Pink (03/02/2014)

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: She loves that bike. Got it for her eighth birthday. (pause) I was right about her age when I hit my first home run. I was so excited I ran all the way home from school. Completely out of my mind. P-O-P. Brought in three runs. Roger never takes his eyes off Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daisy! Slow down around the corners honey. You’re gonna fall. Daisy slows down.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took the stairs two at a time, 'Ma!' I shouted, 'Ma!' I couldn't wait to tell her. I didn't even knock; I just busted right into her bedroom. And there she was, unconscious. Face down on the floor in a pool of her own vomit.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You never told me that.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You were too young. Drank herself to death. I don’t even think your mother knows that. Took me until I was fifty to stop being angry. 81. Something about the way Roger communicates this, his tone the way he looks at Laney and the concern in his eyes, gi it away.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Your brother. Laney takes a minute to process.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m not angry, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Of course you are. They watch Daisy pedal along the driveway.  Pink (03/02/2014) 82.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was thinking, maybe I’1l bring Daisy to the city this summer. Laney’s far away.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call me?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You were in the hospital. I didn’t think it was the right time.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Why didn't you call me for the thirty years before that? Roger doesn’t have an answer.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to get going dad. Can I use your bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Of course. First door on your right. 77 INT. DAISY’S BEDROOM - DAY - SAME 77 Laney walks into Daisy's room. She takes it in: the canop bed, the collection of teddy bears, the doll house. Laney kneels, runs her finger across each of their heads. Then takes the father and drops him in her bag. 78 EXT. ROGER’S HOUSE 78 Laney comes out of the house. A taxi is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I would have been happy to drive you back to your hotel. Laney walks over to Daisy. Gives her a hug.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: It was nice to meet you Daisy. Take good care of your Daddy. Daisy doesn’t really understand this but she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you take care of her, okay?

dialogues.speaker: 78B
dialogues.text: 79 Pink (03/02/2014) 83. Roger understand the implication of Laney’s words. He’1ll it right this time. He opens his arms, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Can I? Laney nods, but barely. Roger wraps his arms around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I never stopped loving you Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I know Dad. Laney steps into the taxi and Roger carefully closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (TO THE DRIVER)
dialogues.text: We can go now. Through the window Laney sees Daisy waving and her father wiping tears from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney sinks. She takes a deep breath, follows it with another no matter how much air she takes in it isn’t enou She can’t seem to catch her breath. She puts her head between her legs and continues to breathe deeply, pulls h head up again, stretches out her back. The taxi driver adjusts his rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney reaches into her bag, takes out her phone and dials The phone rings. We hear Bruce’s voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, you reached Bruce- Laney tosses the phone back into her bag. Deflated. She e the lobby bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney sits down at an empty bar. There is a handsome BARTENDER (early 30's) cleaning glasses, his hair pulled in a ponytail.  Pink (03/02/2014) 84.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What’11 it be?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: A couple of Xanax would be great. Bartender smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You and me both.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: A shot of tequila with a lime. The Bartender prepares her drink, doing away with the requisite shot glass. He sets her drink in front of her. Laney looks at it for a moment, then shoots it.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep em coming okay?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Not a problem, I like the company. Are you staying with us at the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Yes. Laney contemplates him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Minnesota. That's the accent, right?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Sure is.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Dylan, Prince or Replacements?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Went to the same high school Dylan went to.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: You're gonna think I’m crazy.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Never mind.  80 Pink (03/02/2014) 85.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: People must tell you all the time that you look like Jesus. Laney smiles wide - she knows she has him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney’s gown still hangs from the door, perfectly pressed Bruce pulls his suit out of the closet, places it in the garment bag and zips it up. He is packing with some urgen Or is it anger? There is a suitcase on the bed, a small m of clothes waiting to be folded and packed. The hotel roo door opens quietly as Laney tries to slip in without bein heard. Her plan is foiled right away when she sees Bruce. hears her but doesn't bother to turn around. Laney gather her courage.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry Bruce. I fell asleep by the lake. Bruce is silent.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the time I woke up I already missed the ceremony. And then I was too nervous to come back. I didn’t want to disappoint you. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did it go? Were you a huge hit?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I looked for you by the lake Laney. You weren’t there.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Are you saying you don’t believe me?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m saying I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Jesus Bruce--  Pink (03/02/2014) 86.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No. Do NOT try to turn this around and make me look like the bad guy Lane. Saying your lie louder doesn’t make it true. Laney sits on the bed where he's packing. She softens, he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Bruce, just listen. I found a couple Xanax in the bottom of my purse. I know I shouldn’t have taken any but- Bruce grabs Laney’s face in his hand like he’s going to s her neck off.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What the fuck is wrong with you? He squeezes tighter, then lets go.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why is it so easy for you to look me in the eyes and lie to me? He stares at her. Small pools of tears have settled in th corners of Bruce’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you even love me Laney?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Just not enough I guess. He looks at Laney with a mixture of love and regret.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to Atlanta. I have some business there and I need to clear my head. Figure out where we go from here.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: When are you coming back? What about Eli’s piano recital? This is almost comical. He shakes his head. Laney, mother the year.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I'll be back in time. They’1l stay with my sister until I get home.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: What? You don’t trust me?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. He walks toward the door, bag in hand, turns back to Lane

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is my fault. I shouldn’t have brought you. It was too soon.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: So you're just leaving? You’re just leaving me here alone?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You always seem to find your way home eventually. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just don’t know if I want to be there next time you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney unlocks her front door and pulls her suitcase in be her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney parks her bag next to her, looks around and feels t emptiness. Janey’s ballet outfit it on the bench, Eli’s backpack. Laney walks into the family room. Slow but deliberate. INT./EXT. LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 80c Laney turns on a table lamp and gazes at a few photograph her family on the table next to it. She walks over to the window, looks at the basketball court. It’s empty but for ball and Janey’s pink bike.  81 Pink (03/02/2014) 88. INT. PIANO RECITAL — DAY 81 Modest suburban living-room, upright piano, folding chair Eli is wearing a navy sports coat over a Knicks jersey. J plays with her Barbie doll. Laney glances out the window then back to Eli who is doing his eye ritual, blinking ha He seems to have added a new step - he twists his mouth, holds his lips in a tight squeeze, waits a beat, releases then again. A young girl SABRINA (age 10) finishes her recital piece. The AUDIENCE claps. MRS. MATTINGLY (30's), Eli's piano teacher, steps to the front of the room. She gives Sabrina a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MATTINGLY
dialogues.text: Let’s give Sabrina another round of applause. Laney hears a car door slam. She looks out the window and sees Bruce, still with rolling bag, just in time. He walk in, scans the room. There is an empty seat next to Laney he chooses to take a seat in the back. Janey sees him and leaps down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Daddy! She grabs his hand in an effort to lead him to their seat but he doesn’t follow. Instead he scoops her up onto his Ostensibly he doesn’t want to interrupt Mrs. Mattingly bu truth he doesn’t want to be near his wife. Mrs. Mattingly sees him politely sitting in the back.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MATTINGLY
dialogues.text: It’s okay Bruce. This isn’t Carnegie Hall. Go sit with your family. As Bruce makes his way down the aisle we see Laney and El slide over to make room for him. Bruce sits down next to Eli, Janey on his lap. He puts his arm around his son’s shoulder. Eli is twitching away. Laney and Bruce barely m eye contact. MRS. MATTINGLY (CONT’D) So much has been written about Beethoven's deafness but my favorite story is this one. After the first performance of The Ninth, Beethoven stared blankly at his orchestra. A thoughtful musician, realizing he couldn’t hear the clapping, turned Beethoven around to face the audience. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 83 Pink (03/02/2014) 89. MRS. MATTINGLY (CONT’D) It was Beethoven’s eyes, not his ears that conveyed the symphony’s triumph. Now let’s use our eyes and ears while we welcome Eli Brooks to the stage. Eli will be performing the final movement of the Ninth. The Ode to Joy. Eli, all three-foot nine walks up on stage as the audienc politely claps. He takes a seat at the piano. He composes his hands properly but doesn’t begin. This is gut wrenchi His eyes start twitching, his mouth is turning. Laney hol her breath, eyes wide in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Come on Buddy.... Eli goes through another short series of eye twitches and mouth contortions. This moment is taking forever, the roo silent in anticipation. A PARENT subtly turns around to l at Laney for her reaction. Laney sits up straighter, stoi masking her nerves. And then amazingly, without any twitc of the neck, contorting of the mouth, blinking of the eye Eli begins to play - fingers on keys, wrists raised. This, the sound of her son, is, perhaps, the most beautif Laney's ever heard. She secretly exhales and then because she’s overcome with emotion, her eyes fill with tears. Sh can feel Bruce watching her, she turns her head slowly. W their eyes meet there is no malice. Instead a flicker of hope, the mutual acknowledgement of their little boy’s triumph. At that moment, as Eli takes his bow and the roo cheers, all is forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 82
dialogues.text: INT. BROOKS’ HOME - FOYER - DAY - SAME 83 Bruce unlocks the front door and lets everyone into the house. Bingo, wagging his tail, is there to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to take off your shoes. The kids smile. Leave their shoes on the mat. Put their coats on the bench. All the while Laney is trying to comp herself.  84 Pink (03/02/2014) 90.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Why are you crying Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: These are happy tears. Laney walks over to Eli. Kneels.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: E-you were extraordinary today. Breathtaking. I don’t think I’ve ever heard anything more beautiful. Laney puts her hands on Eli’s shoulders. She takes him in Her beautiful boy.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t deserve to be your mother. Bruce is getting anxious about where this conversation ma lead.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Who wants a snack?

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Hot chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: With marshmallows. Bruce glances at Laney. Her smile belies her anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I have to run to the bathroom. I'll meet you there in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney closes the bathroom door, removes the tampon box fr the top shelf and pulls out the familiar white envelope. empties the contents of the envelope onto the floor. She cuts lines, sniffs coke, glances at herself in the mirror Bingo scratches at the bathroom door, he wants to come in Laney ignores him. There is a crash of some sort in the next room. The kids calling her name. Laney does one more line and starts cleaning up in a hurry. She realizes she doesn’t have muc time.  85 86 87 Pink (03/02/2014) 91.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY AND ELI
dialogues.text: Mom. Mooooocoocom!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Laney!

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: One second!

dialogues.speaker: JANEY AND ELI
dialogues.text: Mom! Eli enters the bathroom first, followed by Janey and Bing Laney pretends to be looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I lost my contact. Damn this floor makes -it’s impossible to find- Laney looks up. The three of them are staring at her. She wipes her nose with her sleeve. There is blood on it. The kids are visibly frightened as Bruce leads them out of th bathroom by their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY
dialogues.text: Mommy! What’s wrong with mommy? EXT. DRIVEWAY - DAY -— CONTINUOUS 85 Laney runs out the front door and speeds off.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 86
dialogues.text: INT. DONNY’S OFFICE - DAY - CONTINUOUS 87 Walls covered with advertisements. Directly behind Donny a mock up of the spring ad campaign. A life-sized poster, caricature of Donny's father sitting on top of a cow. Arm in the air, cowboy hat, two lassoed yogurt pops. “The Dai King Rides Again.” Donny is taken aback by the site of Laney: mascara running down her face, crusted blood on he nose. She’s shaking.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I need something to calm down. Donny hands her a tissue, then guides her into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: What happened?  Pink (03/02/2014) 92.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about it. Laney wipes her nose, glances at the tissue. There’s bloo on it. She crumples the tissue into her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I can’t give you anything, Lane. What kind of person would that make me?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Please Donny. Now isn’t the time for moralizing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: But you were just in rehab -

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Well now I’m not. Please! Donny's office phone rings but he ignores it. Instead he wets his thumb, wipes the dry blood from Laney's nose, tu a piece of Laney's hair behind her ear. A tear runs down cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: It’s all going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Not for me. But it is for you - you’re about to have a baby!

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: We'll figure it out. Donny kisses the back of Laney’s neck. Then her mouth. He slips his hand into her blouse. His cell phone rings. He pulls it out of his pocket and looks at the Caller ID.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Suze, what’s up? Donny looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus! Are you at the emergency room? Okay, take a deep breath. What did the doctor say? Is he in pain? I'm on my way. Everything's gonna be okay. Donny hangs up the phone.  88 89 Pink (03/02/2014) 93.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: How many people you going to make everything okay for? Donny shoots Laney a look of disgust.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: This is my son. He grabs his jacket and leaves. Laney opens Donny’s locke desk drawer with a letter opener and rifles through the prescription containers inside. She swallows some pills, stuffs the prescriptions into her purse and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney is walking to her car. Across the street a neon sig flashes: EVERY NIGHT EIGHTIES NIGHT, THURSDAY IS LADIES N 1$ BEERS. INT. O’SULLIVAN’S BAR - DAY - CONTINUOUS 89 Laney takes a seat, eyes the BARTENDER for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Beer. A guy in a QUAKER STATE walks over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: No Springsteen on the jute box? This is Jersey. He glances at Laney.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Springsteen fan?

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: How could you tell? Laney smirks, unimpressed. QUAKER STATE (CONT’D) Best musician on the planet. Put Jersey on the map. Laney lifts the bottle to her mouth. She recognizes the pathetic pick-up attempt but she’s willing to play ball.  Pink (03/02/2014) 94.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: I’m sure Sinatra would argue. And Bon Jovi, and--

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: Bon Jovi? All he ever wanted was to be Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: We all want to be something bigger than we are I guess.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Quaker State moves closer. QUAKER STATE (CONT’D) What did you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Me? Laney tries to make out the tattoo on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: You see me talking to anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: All I wanted was to get married, have kids and live happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: So what's a nice girl like you doing in a place like this? The pills have kicked in, Laney has that all too familiar glaze.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Who said I’m a nice girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney’s cheek is pressed up against a brick wall. There’s trash all around: garbage cans overflowing with debris.  Pink (03/02/2014) 95.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Lick it.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: Lick what baby?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: My ass.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: Your ass? As he bends down to lick her ass, Laney shoves him in an effort to provoke him. She’s looking for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: No more fucker.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: I‘11 tell you when it’s no more. Laney has succeeded in instigating Quaker State. He draws back her head and smashes her face against the brick. As reaches for the wound he pulls her arm back. Laney chuckl inviting more pain.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Fuck. He likes this.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: That hurt?

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Barely felt it. Is that all you got? Quaker State smashes her face into the wall one more time which turns him on even more. He finishes and buttons up pants. She sinks to the pavement and watches as he dumps contents of her purse on the ground. He picks up the cash the two bottles of pills. He stashes the cash and one of bottles in his pocket, takes the lid off the other bottle pours the pills on Laney.

dialogues.speaker: QUAKER STATE
dialogues.text: Want? Laney can't move her lips. The gash on her cheek is throb but she looks remarkably at peace. She got what she wante what she’s certain she deserved.  91 92 93 94 95 Pink (03/02/2014) 96. Laney gives a feeble smirk before she falls into a fog, i and out of consciousness. She tries to get up, falls down again. Did someone try to help her up? Did she hear voice She loses consciousness again. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun begins to rise, Laney opens her eyes and takes second to place herself. She touches her cheek, feels aro for her bag. You can practically smell the alley- the pis the ground, the trash starting to defrost from the nightt cold. She sits up, reaches for her purse and all of her belongings strewn around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney stumbles to her car. She looks for her keys but can find them. She reaches for her iPhone. Her screen saver i an adorable photo of Eli and Janey. We see Laney’s reflection on the screen. Tears rolling down her cheeks. presses the button in her contacts that says, “Valley Cab EXT. LANEY’S STREET - DAWN 93 Laney’s in the back seat of a taxi cab, her face black an blue, dried blood. She’s a mess. We pass the same tall tr painted fences that we passed in the opening scene. The t slows to a stop in front of her house. It’s early morning All the lights are off. Laney opens the taxi door.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: Can you wait? The taxi driver nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney takes the key from under the potted plant, opens th front door and quickly turns the alarm off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laney opens a cabinet and grabs two brown lunch bags. She reaches into a drawer and grabs two bags of organic chips a loaf of bread.  96 Pink (03/02/2014) 97. She opens the fridge, takes out two slices of American cheese, two apples, two juice boxes... Her gestures are steady and precise. Laney is on a mission: she is going t make her children lunch. She makes the sandwiches, cuts off the crusts, slices the into fours, wraps them in tinfoil. Tears roll down her cheeks. She peels the apples, cuts them into bites, rubs with lemon so they won’t brown and places them in a Ziplo She takes out a box of crayons and writes “JANEY” in bubb letters on one lunch bag and “ELI” on the other. She decorates Janey’s bag with hearts and flowers and Eli’s b with basketballs and stars. The scene is tense and heartbreaking. Laney looks around the kitchen. There it is -- her life i full. Toys, photographs, school pictures pasted to the refrigerator, schedules and children’s artwork tacked to cork board. It’s time to go. Laney walks towards the front door, Bing follows. But before she leaves she gets down on her knees kisses him. When she stands up she sees Bruce leaning aga the banister. He looks at Laney with sadness and resignat

dialogues.speaker: JANEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy? Bruce hangs his head down, as if Laney’s battered face is slap to his own.

dialogues.speaker: JANEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daddy? Laney looks up the stairs, then to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (Whispers) I’m sorry. Bruce watches as Laney makes the long short walk to the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver turns on the engine. As Laney steps in she notices the light in Eli’s room come on. She closes the door, presses her hand against the taxi window. Bingo, wagging his tail, is standing with Bruce by the front doo

dialogues.speaker: LANEY
dialogues.text: (to taxi driver) We can go.  Pink (03/02/2014) 98. The taxi makes it’s way down the tree lined street until disappears. CUT TO BLACK.
